explanation: The report is not correct. dev_name is derived by strrchr(phys_path, '/') so it points into the same NUL-terminated string object phys_path. Earlier the function calls OS_CHECK_STRING(phys_path, sizeof(filesys->system_mountpt), ...) which enforces that phys_path is a valid NUL-terminated string within the checked maximum length. memchr(dev_name, 0, sizeof(filesys->volume_name)) will examine at most sizeof(volume_name) bytes starting at dev_name but will stop when it encounters the terminating NUL. Because the NUL terminator for phys_path is guaranteed (by the prior check) to lie within the phys_path object, memchr cannot legally read past the end of that object in normal execution. In other words, the code ensures the string is NUL-terminated and memchr will not run off the end of the string object before seeing that NUL, so this use does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (Using strnlen could be a stylistic alternative, but it is not required here to avoid the reported violation.)
